(12) Mason JB et al; Environ Sci Technol 45: 2243-9 (2011)

StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: Outdoor air concentrations in urban environments are variable and depend on local conditions(1). They are usually 1-20 ug/cu m(1). A major source of formaldehyde in urban air is incomplete combustion of hydrocarbon fuels; urban air concentration in heavy traffic or during severe inversions can range up to 100 ug/cu m(1). The concentration of formaldehyde was measured at various sites in US(7); 26% of 749 samples were positive(2); 25% of samples had concentrations >2.7 ppb with a max concentration of 27 ppb(2). Six cities in US had average concentrations of formaldehyde ranging from 11.3 to 20.6 ppb with a max concentration of 40 ppb(3,4). The daily mean and 1 hr maximum concentration of formaldehyde at 4 cities in New Jersey ranged from 3.8 to 6.6 ppb and 14 to 20 ppb, respectively(5). Two cities in Southern California had concentrations of formaldehyde ranging from 2 to 48 ppb during photochemical smog episodes(6). From Aug 1979 to Aug 1980, the mean and range of concentrations of formaldehyde were 1.28 ppb and 0.11 to 10 ppb (174 samples), respectively, at a moderately polluted area near Julich, Germany(7). The concentration of formaldehyde decreases as one goes up several hundred feet in altitude(8). Formaldehyde residues were monitored for at 13 urban locations in the US from 1996-1997(9). Two locations had mean levels >1 but < 5 ppb, 4 locations had mean levels > 5 but < 10 ppb, and 7 locations had mean levels > 10 ppb(9). Peak formaldehyde concentrations of 16-37 ppb were measured at three sites in Houston TX during the summer of 2006(10). A 12-month monitoring study at a commercial site in Rio de Janeiro Brazil detected a mean formaldehyde concentration of 151 ppb(11). A 2007 monitoring study conducted in communities adjacent to the Ports of Los Angeles and Long Beach detected mean formaldehyde concentrations of 1.76 and 3.03 ppbv in the summer and winter respectively(12).

Reference: (1) Baez AP et al; Environ Pollut 89: 163-7 (1995)
(2) Grosjean D et al; Atmos Environ 24B: 101-6 (1990)
(3) Viras LG et al; Fres Environ Bull 1: 73-8 (1992)
(4) Ferrari CP et al; Chemosphere 37: 1587-601 (1998)
(5) Possanzini M et al; Atmos Environ 30: 3757-64 (1996)
(6) Grosjean D; Environ Sci Technol 25: 710-15 (1991)
(7) Mukund R et al; Atmos Environ 30: 3457-70 (1996)
(8) Liu W et al; Atmos Environ 40: 2202-14 (2006)
(9) Li X et al; Environ Sci Process Impacts 16(2): 291-7 (2014)

StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: The concentration of formaldehyde at the Univ of Mexico campus between Mar-May 1993 ranged from 9.9 to 110.4 ppb(1). Formaldehyde was detected in air from San Paulo, Brazil (range, 8.5-19.3 ppb; July 1988)(2), Athens, Greece (range, 15-25 ppb in Winter 1991; range, 6-20 ppb in Spring 1991)(3), and Grenoble, France (range, 2-18 ppb; May 1995)(4). The concentration of formaldehyde in air from Rome, Italy ranged from 8.8-27.7 ppb between Jun-Jul 1994 and from 8.2-17.6 ppb between Jan-Mar 1995(5). Ambient levels of formaldehyde from 24 samples were collected every day at 6 Southern California locations between 9/2/88 and 9/25/89; average concentrations in Anaheim, Azusa, Burbank, Hawthorne, Upland, and W. Los Angeles, CA were 5.3 ppb (max, 25.3 ppb), 5.0 ppb (max, 20.7 ppb), 6.0 ppb (max, 26.0 ppb), 6.0 ppb (max, 29.4 ppb), 5.3 ppb (max, 29.2 ppb), and 6.1 ppb (max, 25.8 ppb), respectively(6). The average concentration of formaldehyde in ambient air from Columbus, OH (June-July 1989) was 3.8 ug/cu m(7). Outdoor air samples collected at 353 homes in Los Angeles CA, Elizabeth NJ and Houston TX between 1999 and 2001 contained a median formaldehyde concentration of 6.42 ug/cu m(8). Average monthly formaldehyde concentrations ranged from 2.0-10.0 ppbv during April 2010-April 2011 monitoring of ambient air in Shanghai China(9).

Reference: (1) IARC; Monographs on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk of Chemicals to Man. Geneva, Switzerland: WHO 62: 242 (1995)
(2) Council on Environmental Quality; Environmental Quality-1980. p. 185-7 (1980)
(3) Sakai K et al; Environ Res 94: 75-85 (2004)
(4) Buters JTM et al; Environ Sci Technol 41(7): 2622-29 (2007)
(5) Liu W et al; Atmos Environ 40: 2202-2214 (2006)
(6) Loh MM et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 6903-11 (2006)
(7) Wu X et al; Environ Sci Technol 45(20): 9075-83 (2011)
(8) Colton MD et al; Environ Sci Technol 48(14): 7833-41 (2014)

StringWithMarkup.String: INDOOR AIR: The levels of formaldehyde in indoor air are often higher than those outside(1). The concentration in dwellings depend on the sources of formaldehyde that are present, the age of the source materials, ventilation, temperature, and humidity(1). Major sources of formaldehyde in some dwellings have been reported to be off-gassing of urea-formaldehyde foam insulation and particle board(1). The mean level in conventional homes with no urea-formaldehyde foam insulation were 25-60 ug/cu m(1). Studies conducted in Denmark, Sweden, Germany, and the US frequently found indoor formaldehyde levels in excess of 0.12 ppm and in several cases >3.0 ppm(2). In an energy efficient research house, formaldehyde levels were 65 ppb without furniture, 182 ppb with furniture, 212 ppb occupied during day, 114 ppb occupied during night(2). The geometric mean concentration of formaldehyde in indoor air from 37 homes in Nagoya, Japan and 27 homes in Uppsala, Sweden were 17.6 and 8.3 ug/cu m, respectively(3). The indoor air concentration of formaldehyde in a new and used car (both parked) was 94.2 and 24.3 ug/cu m respectively(4). Indoor air samples collected from 353 non-smoking homes in Los Angeles CA, Elizabeth NJ and Houston TX between 1999 and 2001 contained a median formaldehyde concentration of 20.1 ug/cu m(5). Indoor air samples collected at retail stores in Boston during 2003 and 2004 contained geometric mean formaldehyde levels of 19.6 ug/cu m(6); indoor air samples collected at commercial dining facilities in Boston during 2005 contained geometric mean formaldehyde levels of 14.3 ug/cu m(6). A geometric mean formaldehyde concentration of 16.4 ug/cu m was measured in the indoor air of 37 small and medium sized commercial buildings in California(7). In a study of indoor air quality in green versus conventional multifamily low-income housing, differences in formaldehyde were not statistically significant between the two sources(8).

Reference: (1) IARC; Monographs on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk of Chemicals to Man. Geneva, Switzerland: WHO 62: 242 (1995)
(2) National Research Council; Formaldehyde and Other Aldehydes p. 5-13 USEPA 600/6-82-002 (1982)
(3) Hanrahan LP et al; J Air Pollut Control Assoc 35: 1164-7 (1985)
(4) Stock TH; J Air Pollut Control Assoc 37: 913-8 (1987)
(5) Graham LA et al; J Air Waste Manage Assoc 54: 563-84 (2004)
(6) Marchand C et al; Atmos Environ 40: 1336-45 (2006)

StringWithMarkup.String: INDOOR AIR: Many studies have been reported since the late 1970s of formaldehyde levels in mobile homes (caravans)(1). In 3 states, mobile homes (with a filed complaint) had mean levels of formaldehyde ranging from 0.1 to 0.88 ppm and up to 3.0 ppm(2). Non-complaint mobile homes in Wisconsin which were <3 yrs old had a mean concentration of formaldehyde of 0.54 ppm; mobile homes >3 yr old had a mean concentration of 0.19 ppm(3). Homes in Houston, TX were found to have concentrations >0.10 ppm in 19% of those tested(4). The levels of formaldehyde appear to decrease as the mobile home (and its formaldehyde-based resins) age, with a half-life of 4 to 5 years(1). In the early 1980s, a mean level of 0.4 ppm and individual measurements as high as several ppm were measured in new mobile homes. As a result of new standards set in the mid-1980s for building materials used in mobile homes and voluntary reductions by the manufacturers, formaldehyde levels in mobile homes are now typically around 0.1 ppm or less(1). Mean formaldehyde levels in homes with attached garages were 25.6 ng/L (maximum concentration 49 ng/L) following the cold starting of motor vehicles in the garage(5). Indoor air collected at various locations in Strasbourg France contained mean formaldehyde levels of 5.7-55.9 ug/cu m(6).

Reference: (1) IARC; Monographs on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk of Chemicals to Man. Geneva, Switzerland: WHO 62: 242 (1995)
(2) Platt V, Perner D; J Geophys Res 85: 7453-8 (1980)
(3) Zafiriou OC et al; Geophys Res Lett 7: 341-4 (1980)
(4) Fushimi K, Miyake Y; J Geophys Res 85: 7533-6 (1980)
(5) Neitzert V, Seiler W; Geophys Res Lett 8: 79-82 (1981)
(6) Lowe DC et al; Environ Sci Technol 15: 819-23 (1981)
(7) Platt U et al; J Geophys Res 84: 6329-35 (1979)
(8) Mahajan AS et al; J Atmos Chem 66: 167-78 (2010)
(9) McCarthy MC et al; J Air Waste Manage Assoc 56: 3-11 (2006)

StringWithMarkup.String: RURAL/REMOTE: Ambient levels of formaldehyde are generally <1 ug/cu m in remote areas; for example, in the unpopulated Eniwetok Atoll in the Pacific Ocean, a mean of 0.5 ug/cu m and a maximum of 1.0 ug/cu m formaldehyde were measured in outdoor air(1). The average and range of concentrations of formaldehyde in clean marine air are generally <0.5 ppb and <0.03 to 4 ppb, respectively(2-7). Measurements of formaldehyde were made at the Cape Verde Atmospheric Observatory between November 2006 and June 2007 showed that typical formaldehyde mixing ratios ranged between 350 and 550 pptv(8). A 2003 NOAA study to determine background concentrations of 18 toxics in North America determined a formaldehyde level of 0.20 ug/cu m(9).

Section.Description: Information on the amount or concentration of this compound in food, reported from various data sources.

StringWithMarkup.String: Formaldehyde occurs naturally in foods, and foods may be contaminated as a result of fumigation (of e.g. grain), cooking (as a combustion product) and release from formaldehyde resin-based tableware(1). It has been used as a bacteriostatic agent in some foods, such as cheese(1). Fruits and vegetables typically contain 3-60 mg/kg, and meat and fish, 6-20 mg/kg(1). Formaldehyde was identified in volatile emissions from almond shells and hulls at levels of 4.81-6.99 ng/L(2).

StringWithMarkup.String: NIOSH (NOES Survey 1981-1983) has statistically estimated that 1,329,322 workers (441,902 of these are female) are potentially exposed to formaldehyde in the US(1). The NOES Survey does not include farm workers(SRC). Occupational exposure to formaldehyde may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where formaldehyde is produced or used(2). Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to formaldehyde via inhalation of ambient air (indoor and outdoor), inhalation of cigarette smoke, ingestion of food and possibly drinking water, and dermal contact with cosmetics, aerosol products and other consumer products containing formaldehyde(2,3).

Literature references related to scientific contents from Springer Nature journals and books. These references have been ranked automatically by an algorithm which calculates the relevance for each substance in a Springer Nature document. It is based on: (1) the TF-IDF, adapted to chemical structures, (2) location information in the text (e.g. title, abstract, keywords), and (3) the document size.  Springer Nature aims to provide only highly qualitative and relevant content but references of lower relevance aren't withheld as they might contain also very useful information.

Section.Description: Chemical co-occurrences in literature highlight chemicals mentioned together in scientific articles. This may suggest that an important relationship exists between the two. Pharmacologic Class is a group of active moieties that share scientifically documented properties and is defined on the basis of any combination of three attributes of the active moiety: mechanism of action (MOA), physiologic effect (PE) and chemical structure (CS).  An FDA "Established Pharmacologic Class" (EPC) text phrase is a pharmacologic class associated with an approved indication of an active moiety that the FDA has determined to be scientifically valid and clinically meaningful.

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
Reference.LicenseNote: CC-BY 4.0
